text:
“I am late. It’s eleven, isn’t it?” he asked, eyes downcast.  
“Yes,” Sonia muttered, hope flickering. “My landlady’s clock just struck.”  
“I’ve come to you for the last time,” Raskolnikov said gloomily.  
“Are you… going away?”  
“I don’t know. Tomorrow…”  
“Then you’re not coming to Katerina Ivanovna?” Her voice trembled.  
“I’ll know tomorrow morning. But I came to say one word…”  
He noticed she stood while he sat.  
“Why are you standing? Sit down.”  
She sat, and he looked at her kindly.  
“How thin you are! What a hand! Like a dead hand.”  
Sonia smiled faintly.  
“I have always been like that.”  
“Even when you lived at home?”  
“Yes.”  
“Of course, you were.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov visits Sonia for what he believes may be the last time, expressing concern for her well-being while contemplating his uncertain future.
